nodes.text: You spot a figure huddled near the water's edge, their satchel overflowing with plant samples. A half-dryad with leaves tangled in her hair looks up, her expression a mix of relief and exhaustion. 'Oh! Another person! I'm Astrin—I'm a herbalist, but I'm... I'm lost. I was collecting samples and got turned around. The forest paths keep shifting, and I can't find my way back to safety. Do you know where the Glade is? I heard it's a safe place, but I can't seem to find it.'

options.text: I can help you get to the Glade.
I know where it is. Follow me.

nodes.text: I'm... I'm tired, and hungry, and I've been wandering for days. I'm not much of a survivalist—I know plants, not wilderness. I just need to get somewhere safe where I can rest and organize my samples. The Glade is supposed to be safe, right?

options.text: Yes, it's safe. I'll help you get there.

nodes.text: Oh, thank you! I'm so relieved. I've been carrying all these samples, and I'm exhausted. If you can help me get to the Glade, I can set up a proper workspace there. I can brew teas, identify herbs, help you with whatever you need. I just need somewhere safe to work.

Astrin looks up from organizing her samples, a small workspace set up near the charred tree. 'Oh — one of you. Let's see if you actually listen when the trees speak.' She smiles slightly. 'Thank you for helping me get here. I've set up a small workspace, and I'm finally able to organize my samples properly. Is there anything I can help you with? I can brew teas from herbs you bring me, or identify plants you've found.'

options.text: Can you brew teas for me?

nodes.text: Yes! I can brew teas from herbs you bring me. I know several recipes—soothing teas, clarity teas, even a special blend that can help with rapport and understanding. Bring me the herbs, and I'll brew whatever you need. I have a special recipe for a 'Soothe Tea' that can help calm your mind after stressful encounters.

options.text: That sounds useful. What herbs do you need?
I'll bring you some herbs soon.

nodes.text: For the Soothe Tea, I need any calming herb—mint works well, or chamomile if you can find it. Brew it with fresh water, and it'll help ease your mind. I can also make a Rapport Tea if you bring me the right combination—it helps with understanding and connection. Just bring me the herbs when you have them, and I'll brew it for you.

options.text: Thank you. I'll bring you the herbs.

nodes.text: Of course! I can identify most common herbs and plants. Just show me what you've found, and I'll tell you what it is and what it's good for. I'm particularly good with forest herbs—I've been studying them for years. I'm especially interested in rare finds like Heartmore Shoots, Dreammilk Moss, Glow-Tail Larva, Starlace Fungus, and Veilgrass Tufts—they're incredibly valuable for advanced tea brewing.

options.text: What herbs should I look for?

nodes.text: Look for mint near water sources—it's great for calming teas. Dream Fern grows in shaded areas and is useful for meditation and runestone work. Bramble Root can be found near thickets and is good for tool maintenance. And keep an eye out for any unusual plants—the forest is full of surprises, especially with the runestones being repaired. If you find Heartmore Shoots, Dreammilk Moss, Glow-Tail Larva, Starlace Fungus, or Veilgrass Tufts, bring them to me—they're high-value ingredients for my most potent teas.

I'm doing much better now, thank you. The Glade is safe, and I can finally work properly. I've noticed the forest feels different since you've been mending the runestones—the plants are responding, growing more predictably. It's fascinating to observe. I'm glad I can be here to help.

Yes. The plants are responding to the stabilized ley-lines. Herbs are growing in more predictable cycles, and the forest's natural rhythms are returning. It's a good sign—it means your work is making a real difference. The forest remembers itself more clearly now.
Astrin looks up from her work. 'Hello again! Is there anything I can help you with today?'

The forest feels so much calmer now. The magical 'buzz' that used to interfere with my tea brewing has settled. I can work more precisely, and my teas are coming out better. The stabilized ley-lines make everything feel more... harmonious. It's wonderful.

options.text: I'm glad it's helping your work.

nodes.text: Let me take a look at that. Yes, I can identify it for you. This is [herb name], and it's useful for [purpose]. I can help you understand what herbs you've found and how to use them. Just bring me any unidentified plants, and I'll tell you what they are.

I'm working on a special tea blend—something that can help with rest and comfort. If you could bring me three glow-dust units and two calming herbs—mint works well—I can share the recipe with you. It's called Dreamleaf Tea, and it makes resting at the Glade feel more restorative.

Dreamleaf Tea helps you rest more deeply. When you drink it before resting at the Glade, it brings a sense of comfort and safety. It's particularly nice when you're tired or stressed. The Glade feels more like home when you've had a good cup of Dreamleaf Tea.

Perfect! Here's the recipe for Dreamleaf Tea. Brew it with glow-dust and mint, and drink it before you rest at the Glade. It'll help you sleep more deeply and wake up feeling more refreshed. The Glade is already a safe place, but this tea makes it feel even more like home.

options.text: Thank you. This will be very helpful.

nodes.text: You know, for someone without any natural connection to plants, you've been very helpful. Most humans I've met don't pay much attention to the forest's smaller details.
Your keen sense of smell must help you find herbs, wolf-kin. I've noticed you seem to locate patches I might have missed.
I appreciate your steady presence, cow-kin. The Glade feels more peaceful with you around. It helps my plants grow better.
You understand the forest's rhythms better than most, elf. I can see it in how you move through the undergrowth—you never disturb the plants unnecessarily.
Your connection to stone is interesting, dwarf. Some of the best herbs grow near rocky outcroppings—perhaps you could help me find new patches.
Your scales must make you sensitive to temperature changes, lizard-folk. That's useful for knowing when certain herbs are ready to harvest.
Your graceful movements through the forest are a pleasure to watch, deer-kin. You seem to know instinctively where to step to avoid crushing delicate plants.
You're quick to spot things others miss, fox-kin. I've noticed you find herbs in places I wouldn't have thought to look.
Your keen eyes must help you spot herbs from above, gryphon-folk. Though I suppose you're usually on the ground when foraging.
There's something ancient about your presence, dragonborn. The plants seem to respond to it—some of my teas have been more potent since you've been here.
Your form is… substantial. I'll need to make sure my workspace can accommodate you comfortably when you rest here. The Glade welcomes all shapes, though.
You coil so gracefully. I imagine resting here feels different for you—more space to stretch out. The Glade adapts to those who need it.
Four legs must make resting here interesting. I've noticed you settle into the Glade's spaces differently—more naturally, perhaps. The plants don't mind.
You have a… botanical quality. I can sense it—the plants respond to you differently. Some of my teas brew stronger when you're near. It's fascinating.
There's stone in your essence. Interesting—most plants grow better near stone, but you carry it within you. My teas might need different brewing times for you.
You leave a… moist trail. The plants don't mind—some actually seem to appreciate it. Moisture helps them grow, after all.

options.text: I'm glad the plants like it.

nodes.text: You belong here, don't you? The forest recognizes you. My plants grow better when you're around—they sense a kindred spirit.
You're more at home in the dark, aren't you? The Glade's open spaces must feel different. But the plants here don't judge—they welcome all who need rest.

You're… part network. I can sense it—the mycelial threads, the spore connections. I'd love to study this, with your consent, of course. The way the plants respond to you is fascinating. They recognize a kindred structure.

options.text: I'm not sure what you mean.

nodes.text: Your form is… soft. I'll set out a mat for you to sit on—the ground here can be rough. And maybe adjust the cups so they don't slip. The plants don't mind your presence, though. Moisture helps them grow.

Your frame hums. The herbs respond strangely—some curl away, others lean closer. It's like they're trying to understand something that isn't organic. I'm curious, but not alarmed. The Forest accepts all forms.
You have moss on you—or maybe you are moss? Either way, the plants here recognize you. There's a strong affinity. My teas brew stronger when you're near. It's wonderful.
